citation.article-title: Hymenobacter perfusus sp. nov., Hymenobacter flocculans sp. nov. and Hymenobacter metalli sp. nov. three new species isolated from an uranium mine waste water treatment system

p.s: Description of H. metalli sp. nov.
id="par0115">H. metalli (me.taĺli. L. gen. n. metalli, of a mine, from a mining area with metals).
H. metalli forms rod-shaped cells of variable length, 3–5 μm long and 0.5–0.8 μm wide.
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming and motility is not observed.
Colonies on R2A medium are red–pink pigmented and 0.5–1.5 mm in diameter after 48 h growth.
The optimum growth temperature is approximately 25 °C, and growth occurs between 4 °C and 30 °C.
The optimum pH is 6.0–6.5, whereas growth does not occur at pH 5.0 or pH 10.0.
The major respiratory quinone is menaquinone 7.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), an unknown aminophospholipid (APL3), an unknown aminolipid (AL1) and an unknown polar lipid (L1).
The major fatty acids are 15:0 iso, 15:0 anteiso, summed feature 3 (16:1 ω6c and/or ω7c and/or 15:0 iso 2-OH) and summed feature 4 (17:1 anteiso B and/or iso I).
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.

Alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, trypsin, acid phosphatase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, β-galactosidase, α- and β-glucosidase, and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase test positive in API ZYM; other activities test negative.

Biolog GN2 tests show that strain A2-91T oxidizes dextrin, Tween 40, sucrose, monomethyl succinate, d-gluconic acid, d-glucosaminic acid, d-glucuronic acid, succinic acid, glucuronamide, l-asparagine, l-leucine and l-pyroglutamic acid; other substrates from this test were not oxidized by this strain.
Susceptible to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, erythromycin, rifampicin, tetracycline and vancomycin.
The DNA of strain A2-91T has a G+C content of 61.6 mol% (HPLC method).
id="par0120">The type strain A2-91T (=CIP 110140 = LMG 25700) was isolated from the water collected in Poço das Cobras (Urgeiriça mine), central Portugal.
